entry.title: Error while triggering notification using Situation Handling
entry.content:
Hello All,

When attempting to trigger a Fiori notification for Contract Expiry through Situation Handling, we encounter an error stating, "Destination and O'Auth Profile for SAP Cloud Service not maintained" in the SLG1 transaction.

We discovered that the cloud destinations ‘BWZ_Fiori_Notification’ and ‘Z_BWZ_NOTIFICATION’ are required, and without these destinations, situation handling cannot be triggered, even if the rest of the setup is complete.

To enable these destinations, we need access to the SAP Cloud Platform Cockpit, which is currently not activated in our system.

Could you please advise on how we can successfully trigger the Situation Handling notification on the 'On-Premise' system without these cloud configurations?

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: 客户对S/4HANA Public Cloud的账套需求
entry.content:
@JuliaLu ,

Follow below steps:-

1. Scoping Phase (Critical Setup Step)
During initial system setup in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC), select scope items to enable multiple ledgers:
J58 – Enables mandatory 0L ledger (local GAAP).
1GA – Enables 2L ledger (e.g., for Austrian GAAP).
2VA – Enables 3L ledger (e.g., for Chinese GAAP).
Plese note - Important: Ledgers cannot be added/removed after go-live and productive use.

2. Define Accounting Principles
Use the "Manage Your Solution" app or CBC to define:
ATGAAP – Austrian Accounting Standards
CNAP – Chinese Accounting Standards

3. Assign Principles to Ledgers & Company Codes
Assign accounting principles to:
0L → Local GAAP
2L → ATGAAP
3L → CNAP
Activate relevant ledgers for each applicable company code.

4. Configure Valuation Approaches (if needed)
Define different rules per ledger for:
Asset Accounting (e.g., depreciation)
Inventory Valuation
Foreign Currency Valuation

5. Master Data
Ensure master data supports ledger-specific values where applicable (e.g., asset master).

6. Reporting
Use standard reporting apps (e.g., "Financial Statements") to report by ledger (0L, 2L, 3L).

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Error on the connector log details
entry.content:
Hi @user116 

This error message relates to the exception: 'Cannot specify a NULL Key value for reference entity STUD_ID.' It is likely that the number of columns containing user data does not match the number of columns in the header. For example, the header might have 15 columns, while the input file contains only 14 columns of user data. This issue could also indicate other formatting problems, such as missing or incorrect delimiters or end-of-line symbols.

entry.title: Re: (Custom) Idoc: issue when changing data type of a field
entry.content: @Giovanni--  you would need an IDoc version because EDID4 doesn't store versions of segments, so it would have no reference to whether a segment would be new vs. old.

entry.title: Version Control Made Simple with Application Frontend Service
entry.content:
As developers, we all know that deploying a new version of an application can be both exciting and risky. Whether you’re rolling out a minor UI fix or launching a major redesign, the ability to manage multiple versions with confidence is key to a smooth delivery process.

With Application Frontend Service, version management is built in from the start, letting you deploy, view, roll back, and promote frontend versions directly from the CLI or SAP BTP Cockpit. In this post, we’ll show you how it works and how to make the most of it.

Why Version Management Matters

Application Frontend Service allows you to host and serve UI applications in SAP BTP. But what happens when a bug slips through? Or when you need to test a new version without affecting your end users?

That’s where the versioning concept in Application Frontend Service comes in.

Application Frontend Service supports multiple coexisting versions of the same application, each one deployed independently and maintained separately.
In the manifest.json file of your application, you define the version name using the applicationVersion property. This allows you to deploy multiple versions of the same application, all sharing the same application ID but with different version identifiers.

Every version:

  • Has its dedicated version-specific URL
  • Can reference different services and codebases
  • Can be tested or validated in parallel with the current live version

Each application has exactly one active version at any given time. The active version is served from the application’s main URL. All other versions are accessible only via their version-specific URLs.
The active version is the version that is available to the end users.

When you deploy an application, it becomes the active version by default, served at the application’s main URL. But you can also deploy a version without activating it, test it safely, and switch to it later with a single command.

Real-Life Example: Test and Promote with Zero Downtime

Let’s say you’ve deployed version 0.0.1 of your application, myApp, and it’s running smoothly in production. You’re now working on version 0.0.2 with a few improvements or new features. With Application Frontend Service, you can deploy version 0.0.2 without making it active right away.

Each application in Application Frontend Service is assigned a unique main URL when it is first deployed. For example:

https://myapp-wscfr.eu10.appfront.cloud.sap

This main URL always returns the currently active version of the application.

In addition, each deployed version receives its version-specific URL, such as:

https://myapp-wscfr-v0_0_1.eu10.appfront.cloud.sap
https://myapp-wscfr-v0_0_2.eu10.appfront.cloud.sap

With Application Frontend Service, you can:

  • Deploy version 0.0.2 without activating it
  • Access it directly through its version-specific URL:
    https://myapp-wscfr-v0_0_2.eu10.appfront.cloud.sap
  • Let your testers or internal users try it out
  • Keep version 0.0.1 active and served via the main URL
  • Once validated, promote version 0.0.2 to active, and your main URL: https://myapp-wscfr.eu10.appfront.cloud.sap will now serve the new version to all users

All of this happens without downtime, without breaking the existing deployment, and without overwriting any previously deployed version.

Controlling Activation During Deployment

In the previous example, we saw how useful it is to deploy a new version without activating it right away.
By default, any new deployment to the Application Frontend Service becomes the active version. But if you want to delay activation, for example, to perform internal validation, you can control this behavior in two ways, depending on how you deploy.

When deploying an application using the GACD (Generic Application Content Deployer) module

If you are deploying a multi-target application (MTA), you can prevent automatic activation by setting activateVersion: false under the parameters of the GACD module in your mta.yaml file:

...
  parameters:
    config:
      activateVersion: false
      destinations:
        - name: ui5
          url: https://ui5.sap.com

When deploying with afctl push

If you're using the Application Frontend service CLI to deploy applications, you can achieve the same behavior using one of the following options:

  • Pass the --no-activate (or-n) flag to the afctl push command:
afctl push <path-to-app> -n
  • Or set "activateVersion": false in the configuration file (e.g., conf.json):
{
  "activateVersion": false
}

Note: If both the CLI flag and the configuration file contain activation settings, the CLI flag takes precedence.

For example, the following command uses a configuration file that may contain "activateVersion": true, but the -n flag overrides it and prevents activation:

afctl push <path-to-app> -c conf.json -n

With either method, the new version will be deployed and accessible via its version-specific URL. Still, the application’s main URL will continue to serve the currently active version until you explicitly promote the new one.

Managing Application Versions in SAP BTP Cockpit

To access the Application Frontend UI in SAP BTP Cockpit, your user must be assigned the Application Frontend Viewer role. To activate or delete versions, you need the Application Frontend Developer role.

Viewing Your Applications

  1. In the left-hand navigation bar of the SAP BTP Cockpit, choose HTML5 / Application Frontend.
  2. You'll see a list of applications that have been deployed to the Application Frontend Service in your subaccount.
  3. For each application, you can see its active version.
  4. To open and run an application, you can click either the application name or the active version.
  5. If you choose to delete an application, all of its versions (including the active one) will be permanently deleted.

Viewing and Managing Versions

To see all deployed versions of an application:

  1. Click anywhere on the row of the application.
  2. A detail pane will open on the right, showing all the deployed versions of that application.

Here you can activate versions, delete them, or view logs for a specific version.

To change the active version of an application:

  • Click the Activate version icon on the version you want to promote.
  • The active version indicator will move to that version.

Only one version of an application can be active at a time.

To delete a specific version of an application:

  • Click the Delete icon on the version you want to remove

Note: This action is permanent. Deleted versions cannot be recovered.

Additional Notes

  • You cannot delete an active version. To delete an active version, you must first activate another one.
  • An application can have a maximum of 10 versions. Once this limit is reached, you must delete older versions before deploying new ones.

Let’s see how all of this looks in a real example.

I have deployed an application called “employees.” It currently has a single version, 1.0.0, which was activated by default on deployment.

This is how the application looks:

Note the URL. This is the main URL of the application.

I can also run the same version using its version-specific URL:

Now I want to enhance the application by adding search and sort controls, and I also want to remove the “Employees Overview” title.

After making these changes, I deploy version 2.0.0 of the application using the --no-activate flag, meaning this version will not become active immediately.

At this point, two versions of the application exist:

Since the new version was not activated, the main application URL still serves version 1.0.0 - without the new features:

However, I can access and test version 2.0.0 using its version-specific URL:

The search and sort controls are visible, and everything is working as expected.

Next, I activate version 2.0.0.

Now version 2.0.0 is active.

The main application URL serves the updated version with the new features:

The previous version, 1.0.0, remains available through its version-specific URL, and I can roll back to it if needed:

Managing Application Versions with the Application Frontend Service CLI

You can perform the same version management actions using the Application Frontend service CLI.
To activate or delete versions, you need the Application Frontend Developer role.

Activate a version

To activate a specific version of an application, use:

afctl activate APPLICATION VERSION

Arguments:

  • APPLICATION – Name of the deployed application
  • VERSION – Name of the application version you want to activate

Delete a version

To delete a specific version:

afctl delete APPLICATION VERSION

Caution: If you don't specify an application version, all versions of the application will be deleted. This action cannot be undone.

View all versions
To view versions, your user must be assigned the Application Frontend Viewer role.

To list all deployed versions of an application:

afctl list APPLICATION

For example, if you run afctl list employees after activating version 2.0.0 in the example above, the output would show all available versions, including the active one.

As you can see, with built-in versioning and flexible deployment options, Application Frontend Service makes it easy to deliver updates with confidence.
Whether you work in the SAP BTP Cockpit or prefer the CLI, you can roll out changes safely without impacting the live version during development or testing.

entry.title: Unlock the Full Potential of Your People Data with SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals
entry.content:
If you're using SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central but haven’t yet implemented SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, you may be missing out on key opportunities to elevate employee development and unlock the full potential of your workforce and of your investment in SAP SuccessFactors HCM.

Calendars full of meetings, many projects happening simultaneously, and employees working overtime can create an illusion of advancement, but movement is not the same as progress. Real success only comes when teams are moving forward with purpose and intentional effort. And when it comes to workforce development path, leaders need to provide the right guidance to their teams. Without proper guidance, employees will constantly second-guess every decision and worry about not reaching their goals. Without process, goals become unclear, feedback is sporadic, and course correction feels impossible. Your organization might get to the expected results, but not as efficiently as they could.

SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals offers an intuitive and modern experience to help your employees become better versions of themselves, and it works seamlessly with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to transform your people data into a foundation for high-impact performance management, without disrupting the user experience your employees already know. This combination allows organizations to equip their leaders and employees with the insights, structure, and real-time feedback needed to efficiently achieve goals and be ready for any challenges along the way or in the future.

By integrating employee data directly from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, the SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals solution enables smarter, more dynamic performance management processes. Performance forms can be automatically launched when an employee changes departments, locations, or managers, driven by rules configured in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. Additionally, when manager changes occur, forms are automatically rerouted, ensuring the right people are always involved in the review process.

Customizable configuration: enable alerts and change management form rerouting

The combination of these two solutions also allows for support for concurrent employment and global assignments, adding flexibility to assign separate performance reviews when needed. It also enables calibration alerts based on performance and demographic data, helping drive fairer, more informed talent decisions.

People profile cards within performance forms 

And this experience is further enhanced by Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, which works seamlessly within the familiar, user-friendly interface your teams already know, no major changes or retraining required.

Joule assists in goal creation, helping employees and managers align development objectives with organizational priorities, and creates a culture of continuous feedback, with timely insights and nudges for check-ins and development tracking in the flow of work.

Feedback in the flow of work with Joule, SAP's AI copilot 

Managers also benefit from intelligent recommendations that offer visibility into employee growth, while a unified skills foundation across SAP Business Suite supports a consistent, transparent approach to talent management. With the talent intelligence hub, your managers can maintain a single source of truth for skills, enabling them to truly understand and develop their team at every stage, from hiring to feedback to long-term growth.

And employees can explore career aspirations and receive personalized skill recommendations, while tools like 360-degree reviews and performance management forms ensure skills are validated and developed based on real data.

Skills inference  in the growth portfolio

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central and SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals work together to move your organization beyond disconnected processes and unlock a powerful, unified approach to workforce development. This integration turns data into strategic insight, aligning goals, streamlining reviews, and embedding feedback into the everyday flow of work. With AI-driven support and a shared skills foundation, your organization can ensure every employee is seen, supported, and set up to grow. It’s not just about managing performance - it’s about empowering your people to thrive with clarity, purpose, and direction.

Want to learn more about the power of data-driven performance management? Join our upcoming demo webinar to see how you can automate performance cycles, increase visibility into employee growth, and deliver a truly connected talent experience.

[Register Now for the Live Demo]

entry.title: One Pricing Scheme to Rule Them All? Finding the Right Balance in Pricing Configuration
entry.content:
Introduction: The Configuration Expert's Dilemma

Imagine you're configuring pricing for a new portfolio of high-tech medical devices. Each device has a monthly rental fee and a
pay-per-use charge. How do you structure this in SAP Subscription Billing? Do you build completely separate, siloed pricing models for every single product? Or is there a smarter, more maintainable way to reuse components?

This common challenge sits at the heart of efficient configuration. In this post, we'll explore a best-practice approach for
building a scalable and maintainable pricing structure. We will demonstrate how to create reusable components that can handle both recurring and usage-based charges within a single, elegant framework.

 

The Foundation: How Subscription Billing Orchestrates Pricing

Before diving into our example, it's crucial to understand how the pieces fit together. In SAP Subscription Billing, a product's
pricing model consists of two key elements:

  • Rate plan templates: These define the commercial aspects of a product, such as a recurring monthly fee or a usage-based fee,
    and their billing cycle. They can be reused for multiple products that share the same charging model.
  • Pricing schemes: This component defines how a price is calculated. It contains the detailed pricing logic and is assigned
    within a rate plan template to execute the actual price calculation.

When you design a pricing scheme, you must know the context in which it will be used. A critical concept to grasp is that the entire pricing scheme is executed for each charge in the rate plan. If your product has both a recurring and a usage-based fee, the pricing scheme runs twice – once for each fee. This means your pricing logic must be smart enough to know when to act and when to stand down, skipping calculations that aren't relevant to the charge currently being processed.

 

The Core Challenge: Input Fields and Reusability

The reusability of any pricing component, like a lookup table or a pricing logic, is determined by its required input fields. To make a price calculation, the system needs data. This data can come from several sources:

  • Standard Fields: These are always available in the pricing context, such as productCode, marketId, or the rateElement  that distinguishes between charge types.
  • Custom Fields: For more specific requirements, you can map custom fields from the subscription item or other sources into the pricing context.

Here lies the central trade-off: the more specialized the input fields, the less reusable the component. For example, if a recurring charge needs a custom field like Z_CustomerType to determine a price, but a usage-based charge does not, they cannot share the same lookup logic if that logic depends on Z_CustomerType.
This is why creating distinct price element specifications for each charge type is the most robust and maintainable approach. Our goal is to make these individual specifications efficient by having them share common, reusable components like lookup tables wherever the input fields align.

 

A Practical Example: The Reusable Medical Equipment Model

Let's configure our medical device scenario: a diagnostic imaging device priced with a recurring monthly fee and a usage-based fee per imaging procedure. The recurring fee also receives a discount based on the market (e.g., Europe vs. North America). We'll use the rate element BASE_FEE for the recurring charge and IMAGING_PROC  for the usage-based charge.

Step 1: The Core of Reusability - Centralized Lookup Tables

To maximize maintainability, we'll centralize our product-specific prices in shared lookup tables. This empowers a Pricing
Specialist to update rates in a single location, reducing effort and risk.

This centralized design offers a significant operational advantage for the Pricing Specialists responsible for day-to-day price
management. Instead of navigating multiple tables for different charge types, they have a single source of truth for a product's
rates. This not only streamlines the process of updating prices but also simplifies localization and removes any ambiguity about which table governs a specific product.

  • Z_MD_DeviceRates: This table will hold the core prices for both charge types.
    • Input: productCode, marketId, rateElement
    • Output: price

  • Z_MD_RegionalDiscount: This table stores our market-specific discounts.
    • Input: productCode, marketId
    • Output: discount

For example, this table would contain entries defining a 10% discount for the EUROPE market and 5% for NA.

Step 2a: Building the Recurring Charge Logic

Create a price element specification named Z_MD_RecurringFee. In its pricing tree, the logic is as follows:

  1. First, check if the ratingType is 'recurring'. This is the key step that ensures this logic only runs for recurring charges.
  2. Read the price condition from Z_MD_DeviceRates using the productCode, marketId, and rateElement from the input.
  3. Calculate the final amount using the quantity, the retrieved price condition and the prorata field as ratio. This ratio is necessary because recurring fees are typically prorated during subscription changes.
  4. If no matching entry is found in the lookup table, the calculation for this price element is skipped.

Crucially, you must set the conditionType. On Z_MD_RecurringFee, navigate to the "Output Attributes" tab and set the
conditionType to PMP2. This standard setting is vital for correct integration with SAP S/4HANA.

 

Step 2b: Building the Usage Charge Logic

Next, create Z_MD_UsageFee for the charge per imaging procedure.

  1. Check if the ratingType is 'usage'. This isolates the logic to usage-based charges only.
  2. Read the price condition from our central Z_MD_DeviceRates table.
  3. Calculate the usage amount.
  4. If no matching entry is found in the lookup table, the calculation for this price element is skipped.

Notice the core lookup and calculation logic is similar to the recurring fee, but differs in the support for proration.

For this specification, set the conditionType to PMP3.
Using a separate price element specification is the clean and recommended approach, as it correctly isolates both the unique calculation logic and the distinct condition type for the usage-based charge.

Step 2c: Building an Interdependent Discount Logic

Finally, create a separate price element specification, Z_MD_RegionalDiscount. This modularity is a best practice.

For this component, we will introduce a more powerful technique. Instead of explicitly checking the ratingType again, we will make this discount logic dependent on the recurring fee calculation. It will only execute if the recurring fee has a calculated value. We achieve this by using the result of the recurring fee step as an input for the discount calculation, a property known as the Reference Price.

The logic in Z_MD_RegionalDiscount is therefore clean and direct:

  1. Verify first if the Reference Price has been provided. This check implicitly ensures that the discount is only processed when a base fee (our reference) has been successfully calculated.
  2. Read the discount condition from Z_MD_RegionalDiscount using the productCode and marketId.
  3. Calculate the discount amount. Apply the retrieved discount percentage to the Reference Price.

This dependency is formally established in the next section when we assemble our pricing scheme. There, we will configure the output of the recurring fee step to be the reference price for this discount step. This is a cleaner approach as it builds a logical dependency directly into the structure, rather than relying on a separate field check.

For its conditionType, set it to DRV1, a standard type for subscription discounts in S/4HANA.

Step 3: Assembling the Final Pricing Scheme

Now, we assemble our components into a single pricing scheme, Z_MD_MedDevices. We add our three price element specifications in sequence.
Crucially, when adding the Z_MD_RegionalDiscount step, we configure it to use the result of the Z_MD_RecurringFee step as its input. This is what provides the reference price and formally establishes the dependency we designed in Step 2c. When the scheme runs for a usage charge, the recurring fee step is skipped, no reference price is passed, and the discount logic is therefore also correctly skipped.

 

Verification: Analyzing Our Configuration

How do we know our configuration works as intended without creating actual subscriptions? The Analyze Pricing Document app is the perfect tool for this. It allows you to simulate how the pricing scheme will behave.

We create an analysis document with two items: one for the recurring charge (rateElement = BASE_FEE) and one for the usage-based charge (rateElement = IMAGING_PROC).

When we execute the analysis for a European market, the results prove our logic is correct. Item 1 shows the base monthly fee and the regional discount as separate line items, summing to the correct net price. Item 2 shows only the calculated usage-based fee.

 

Alternative Approaches & Common Pitfalls

Pitfall 1: Filtering on rate element instead of rating type

A common first thought is to check for a specific rate element name in your logic (e.g., "If the string [rateElement] is equal to ["BASE_FEE"]"). While this works, it tightly couples your logic to a name and destroys reusability. If you later introduce a new recurring rate element called MONTHLY_SUPPORT, that logic would fail. By checking for the generic rating type ('recurring' or 'usage'), you create a truly reusable component.

Pitfall 2: Dynamically Setting the Condition Type from a Lookup Table

To maximize reuse, you might be tempted to combine Z_MD_RecurringFee and Z_MD_UsageFee into a single, generic price element specification. The idea would be to dynamically read the condition type from a lookup table instead of setting it statically.

While this is technically possible, we advise caution with this pattern. Specifically, you should avoid adding a conditionType
column to your primary, business-facing price tables (like Z_MD_DeviceRates in our example). This approach burdens the Pricing Specialist with the responsibility of maintaining technical S/4HANA integration codes, a task that falls outside their typical role and increases the risk of errors.

For the vast majority of use cases, the clearest and safest approach is the one we have shown: explicitly setting the field conditionType on each distinct price element specification. This method keeps business logic (prices) cleanly separated from technical integration details and ensures your configuration is transparent and easy to support.

Hint: Standard vs. Custom Condition Types

We used standard condition types (PMP2, PMP3, DRV1) pre-configured for S/4HANA integration. However, you can absolutely use your own custom condition types (e.g., ZREC, ZUSG, ZDSC) defined in S/4HANA, as long as they are managed consistently across both systems.

A Note on SAP's Predefined Content

You might notice that SAP's predefined content uses three separate lookup tables for recurring, one-time, and usage-based charges. This is not a contradiction, but a perfect example of this post's core principles in action.

The usage-based table is necessarily separate because it requires an additional input field (rateSubElement), making a shared structure impossible. The recurring and one-time tables are also kept distinct by design for maximum out-of-the-box clarity. This standard configuration validates our key rule: centralize lookup tables only when the input fields are identical, and always prioritize a clear, maintainable design.

 

Conclusion: Your Guiding Principles for Reusability

So, is the answer to "One Scheme to Rule Them All?" a resounding "no." The best practice is to build pricing schemes tailored for
sets of products that share the same fundamental pricing logic. The art lies in creating reusable, modular components within that
scheme.

This approach makes your pricing model easier to maintain, less error-prone, and more scalable. To recap the critical rules:

  • Centralize your pricing data in shared lookup tables to create a single source of truth for your Pricing Specialists,
    simplifying maintenance. Remember, this is only possible when the charges share the exact same set of input fields.
  • Use separate price element specifications for each distinct business charge (e.g., base fee, discount, usage fee). This promotes modularity.
  • Control execution flow within your pricing logic by checking the generic ratingType, not specific rateElement names.
  • Always set the conditionType explicitly on the price element specification for clear and reliable S/4HANA integration.

I hope this guide provides a clear blueprint for building reusable and maintainable pricing models in SAP Subscription Billing. Your real-world scenarios and insights are incredibly valuable. Please share your thoughts, questions, or alternative approaches in the comments below. Let's use this space to learn from each other as a community.

 

Further Reading

  • SAP Help Portal: Pricing
  • SAP Help Portal: Pricing Configuration Guide

entry.title: Re: How to download report to excel with "group by" infor...
entry.content:
Hello @Grace_Li1 

Yes, in SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, the Group By in Fiori apps like Manage Supplier Line Items is a UI-only feature. When you export to Excel, it always downloads flat line items without the group headers or subtotals. There's no setting to include grouping in the export.

If you need grouped data in Excel, your options are:

  1. Use Excel PivotTables after export.
  2. Build a Custom Analytical Query that includes grouping and totals at the data level.
  3. Use Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud if scoped

Fiori elements – Export to Microsoft Excel via the UI Adaptation Editor

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Team Goals creation and derivation to a non hierarchical team with some particularities
entry.content:
REQUIREMENT: Individual Creation of a Goal and derivation of the Goal with Team Goals >> Individual weight set by each employee >> % of Achievement set by owner for all employees the same.

  1. Goal Setting --> Employee (goal owner) sets the goal and creates a Team Goal à makes the employees with whom they have shared the goal co-owners.
  • In this same phase, the employee (co-owner) edits the goal weight.
  1. Manager Validation --> the hierarchical manager is required to validate the goals (Team Goals).
  2. Follow-up (BPO sends back) --> we can propose a first evaluation for the goal owner.
  3. Evaluation --> the % Achievement is given by the goal owner and is the same for all those who have the same Team Goal.
  • The Functional Manager/Custom Manager (objective owner) will appear in the Route Map, and we need to leave the % Achievement field open in the objective plan so that the objective owner can include it.
  • Since the objective owner will be an employee documented in the Employee Profile>>Job Relationships as a Matrix Manager/Custom Manager, in the objective plan, we will have the Employee (objective owner) and other employees edit based on whether they are owners or co-owners (Matrix Manager/Custom Manager or Employee) , and in the PM form, we will restrict it based on the Matrix Manager/Custom Manager or Employee roles.
  • Team Goals: The objective content will remain synchronized, including the % Achievement entered by the objective owner.
  1. Completed

TEAM GOAL ASSUMPTIONS:

  1. Team Goals can be created and shared with anyone (they don't have to be from your same reporting structure to be shared).
  2. A Team Goal works like a shared goal; the goal information is synchronized (what the goal owner updates is transferred on to the rest of the employees who own the Team Goal).
  3. Once the Team Goals are established, a co-owner can edit the Team Goal fields establishing it by permissions of fields to co-owners. Question: If a co-owner edits the weight, is it synchronized with the main goal? The weight must be individual per Employee.

Expert Answer: Before you assign the goal to the employee, the owner can make edits. If the Employee has permission to edit fields, they can make edits. And the edits of those fields, changes made by the employee are not sent back. If changes are made to the original goal, it's not certain whether they will be overwritten.

  1. We could restrict permissions by status and step in a goal plan template linked to a PM Form, but we cannot restrict segmented permissions for the same Role E (Employee).

QUESTIONS FOR SAP:

  • Main issue: How can we restrict permissions for Team Goals when building different status blocks in the Goal Plan, if the Employee (goal owner) sets the % Achievement and not the Manager?

If we create another goal template for Team Goals by Company:

  • Question 1: We need Role E (Employee) to set the goal in step 1. Goal Setting (and be able to edit all fields), and other co-owners can only edit the weight in this step.
  • We need to set different permissions for the same role E (Employee) in the Goal Plan, and this is not feasible. Within the Goal Plan, can we restrict this by owner and co-owner?
  • Question 2: We need Role E (Employee) to evaluate the objectives in step 4. Evaluation (edit the % Achievement field), and other co-owners cannot edit any fields in this step (only view all plan fields).
  • Again, can we restrict this by owner and co-owner in the Objective Plan?
  • NOTE: To transfer these requirements from step 1. Goal Setting and step 4. Manager Evaluation to a PM form, it must be a specific PM&GM role.
  • Example: Matrix Manager/Custom Manager defined in the Employee Profile, who defines the Team Goals in step 1. Goal Setting and editing the % Achievement in step 4. Evaluation.

We need SAP to confirm the following:

  • Role Differentiation in the PM Form --> We have seen that it is possible to differentiate in the Objective Plan by owner and co-owner (to grant editing permissions to certain fields), because with standard Role E (Employee), this is not possible. This is supported in the Objective Plan, but it is likely that the PM form does not, and we will have to establish this person as a Matrix Manager/Custom Manager/Specific User.
  • Role Differentiation in the Objective Plan --> that the Employee (Objective Owner) is a Matrix Manager/Custom Manager, so that permissions are respected in the Objective Plan: very important for step 1, Goal Setting (EX edits everything, and Employees only weight), and in step 4, Evaluation (EX edits % Achievement, and Employees nothing; they only view).

entry.title: Re: Adaptation Project for Post Outgoing Payment (F1612)
entry.content:
Hello @Mahfi 

This is a known issue. App F1612 (Post Outgoing Payments) uses internal SAP libraries (clearing logic) that are not accessible to adaptation projects under custom namespaces. That’s why it works in Preview but fails after deployment with the error about unknown consumer.

SAP does not officially support adaptation projects for this app. Use App Variants for layout changes or check In-App Extensibility if scoped. For logic changes, you'd need to raise a feature request or support ticket.

Extending an SAP Fiori Application for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP BTP, ABAP Environment

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: A Strategic Advantage of Transforming Your Supply Chain with SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP)
entry.content:
In today's dynamic market, a resilient and agile supply chain is not just an operational necessity, it is a competitive differentiator. For business and technology leaders, the time to modernize legacy supply chain systems is now. SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) offers a robust, future-proof solution that delivers tangible benefits.

Why Moving from SAP APO, ERP, or Legacy-Based Supply Chain Planning to SAP IBP is Your Next Strategic Investment:

1. Unified & Intelligent Planning:

  • One Source of Truth: SAP IBP provides a common data model across strategic, tactical, and operational planning, eliminating silos and ensuring consistency from end-to-end.
  • AI-Powered Network Insights: Embedded AI with Conversational, Agentic and network capabilities enable advanced planning beyond your organizational boundaries, both upstream and downstream, for smarter, more proactive decisions.

2. Agility & User Empowerment:

  • Self-Service & Flexibility: Business users can independently make changes, generate reports, and conduct analytics without constant IT intervention. Planners can even execute data and network changes in the live system.
  • Seamless Integration: With an open architecture and native real-time integration to SAP ERP (ECC/S/4HANA/Cloud ERP) and other application platforms, SAP IBP ensures data fluidity and process interoperability across your enterprise.

3. Rapid Value & Future Readiness:

  • Quick Time to Value: Out-of-the-box capabilities and pre-configured industry processes (25+) mean faster implementation and quicker realization of benefits.
  • Scalable & Low TCO: Designed for scalability without customization, SAP IBP reduces maintenance burdens and delivers high ROI and a low Total Cost of Ownership.
  • Continuous Innovation: SAP's strong commitment to investment means quarterly feature releases, near-zero downtime upgrades, and a roadmap shaped by customer feedback, ensuring your supply chain stays ahead of the curve.

The Bottom Line:

SAP IBP is not just another planning tool; it is a comprehensive platform that empowers your organization with real-time visibility, intelligent decision-making, and unparalleled agility. Investing in SAP IBP means investing in a supply chain that can adapt, innovate, and drive significant business value.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible for a reservation created from a MO to...
entry.content:
Hello @JK_ 

By standard, a reservation from a maintenance order posts one debit and one credit per goods issue line. If you need to post to multiple accounts, you can either split the cost across components in the order (with different account assignments) or use manual cost allocations after posting. Direct multi-account debit from a single line isn’t supported.

SAP Help – Maintenance Order Goods Movement

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: The Return of SAP Community Voice!
entry.content:
Last seen in October of last year, SAP Community Voice was our online newsletter, replacing the email version that had gone out to subscribers for many years. Now after a long hiatus, we’re bringing the online edition back!

SAP Community Voice highlights popular posts, important community news, upcoming events, and more. If you’re interested in hot SAP Community content and announcements, look no further. You’ll find it all summarized here.

This edition covers items from the last four weeks or so, and future editions will aim to deliver even more timely information on a regular basis. Make sure to subscribe to the SAP Community Voice label so you don’t miss any issues of our online newsletter!

 

Featured Content

 

Heartiest Congratulations to Our Newest SAP Champions!

SAP Champions include some of the best and brightest SAP Community members, and this month, my colleague @KatherineKenneally welcomes eight new people to the program. To learn more about them (and about the program), check out her post and find out how you can connect with SAP Champions in your region!

Read the blog post

 

The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code

Prolific SAP Community contributor @Marian_Zeis has published a blog post that will help you trigger OData actions and functions from UI5 like a pro -- no matter whether you’re using SAP Fiori elements or going purely freestyle (v2 or v4). This guide walks through every official API, shows exactly when to pick each one, and more.

Read the blog post

 

SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

In this post, SAP’s @Ammar_Naji points out that SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud are core components of SAP Business Data Cloud -- and that they soon won’t be on the list of eligible services under certain subscriptions. He explains what customers can do to prepare for these changes.

Read the blog post

 

Tree View in the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Implementing a tree view in the ABAP RESTful application programming model requires different entities, and author @Vivek_Sahu_21 covers how you can show structured, hierarchical data -- in a parent-child format -- that UI applications and analytics tools can consume easily, providing a smooth user experience.

Read the blog post

 

Community News

 

“Blog It Forward” Is Back and Better Than Ever!

Blog It Forward is one of the longest-running initiatives in our community, dating all the way back to 2012 with this post from my colleague @moshenaveh. SAP Champion @Sandra_Solis brought the series back earlier this year with this post, and since then, several other members have contributed their own posts. The series allows members to introduce themselves while nominating other peers to participate, bringing the community closer together. Check out the Blog It Forward label to find all of the latest posts in this series, subscribe to the label to get updates when new posts appear, and consider writing one of your own!

 

Differentiating DSA Violations from Common Moderation Issues

We have taken steps to make our moderation process friendlier while ensuring that SAP Community continues to comply with the Digital Services Act (DSA). In this recent post, we outline the steps that members now should take when reporting inappropriate content to our moderation team, differentiating between common issues (e.g., incorrect tags) and true DSA violations.

 

Basic Etiquette and Tips for Participating in SAP Community

We are expanding the knowledge base in the Welcome Corner with new resources meant to help members get the most out of their SAP Community experience. In the latest post, we cover the type of behavior we expect from members, offer advice for friendly member interactions, indicate when to notify moderators, and more. Whether you’re a long-time community member or just getting started, you’ll benefit from the guidance in this document.

 

Upcoming Events

 

Registration Is Live for SAP TechEd 2025

SAP TechEd is scheduled for November, and this year, we’re building a hybrid experience that brings together the best of both worlds -- a full in-person experience in Berlin and a customized virtual experience for audiences around the world. Learn more about this exciting event in this blog post from SAP's @cecihuergo and register today for SAP TechEd!

 

Find SAP CodeJam Events in Your Region

SAP CodeJam events bring together developers who want hands-on learning about SAP technology, solutions, and applications. In August, you can attend SAP CodeJam sessions in Lima (Peru), Mexico City, Bogota (Colombia), and Wroclaw (Poland). Visit the SAP CodeJam activity group to learn more about these events, and check out the full list of upcoming events.

entry.title: Re: Error while triggering notification using Situation H...
entry.content:
Hello Jahnavi4,
 
i recently ran into the same (mostly the same) issue while trying to implement Situation Handling for contract expiry notifications in our on-premise S/4HANA system. Although the Situation Type and logic were configured correctly, the system failed to trigger the notification and threw the following error in transaction SLG1:
"Destination and O'Auth Profile for SAP Cloud Service not maintained"
 
After some investigation, i discovered that this error is related to the absence of required SAP BTP cloud destinations, such as:
 
  • BWZ_Fiori_Notification
  • Z_BWZ_NOTIFICATION
 
These destinations are typically used to route notifications through the SAP Launchpad Service (on BTP). Since our landscape does not have BTP or a configured Cloud Connector, we needed an alternative to enable notifications purely within our on-premise setup.
Below is are my notes how i solved this problem:
 
1.) Set Notification Channel to Fiori Launchpad
     Transaction: SITN_SETTINGS --> Notification Channel option --> Set it to: Fiori Launchpad
   
2.) Verify Situation Type Configuration  Transaction: SITNADMIN --> Situation Type = Active --> set Trigger Conditions.
 
3.) Enable Notifications for the User in Fiori Launchpad
   Fiori Launchpad --> user settings --> Notification Settings --> Notifications = enabled
 
4.) Check Gateway and Notification Services
/IWNGW/BEP_NOTIF = LOCAL 
 
 
maybe my solution will help you
Greetings Dom

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to create standard 'tax ledger' in pub...
entry.content:
Hi,

Currently, it is not possible in S4H Cloud to create or re-use on of the other ledgers for tax valuation aka "Tax Ledger". Such approach demands a dedicated custom specific accounting principle which cannot be created. Therefore, such an approach is neither recommended nor supported in any way. 

Best regards,
 Mick

entry.title: Inside SAP Series Mid-Year Wrap-Up: Powered by Practice, Driven by Data
entry.content:
As we head into the summer break, it’s the perfect time to reflect on what we’ve explored so far in this year’s Inside SAP series. Designed to give an inside look into how SAP’s IT organization drives innovation from within, the series features experts from across CPIT sharing real-world insights into how we use our own technology to transform the enterprise.

We opened the 2025 season with a clear message: transformation starts at home. In the first session, Oliver Gutzeit took us behind the scenes of SAP’s digital landscape, demonstrating how we bring together AI, data, processes, and applications to create real business impact.

The following three sessions focused on one of the most powerful enablers of that transformation: data. We explored how SAP is shaping a modern data architecture strategy to fuel both AI innovation and smarter decision-making. From building semantically rich data products, to scaling data and machine learning capabilities, to enabling broader access through data democratization efforts, the series offered valuable insights into how data is evolving into a strategic asset throughout SAP.

The importance of easy to consume and available data, as well as the mind shift needed to achieve this, were part of the session delivered by Oliver Huth, Head of Platform – SAP Enterprise Analytics. He captured the idea with the following analogy and visual illustration:

“We only create a data product if there's a need—just like a coke drink in the supermarket: it has to be well-placed, accessible, easy to consume, and trustworthy. You should be able to pick it up, use it immediately, and even combine it with others—because the real value comes when data products are interoperable and share the same semantics.”

Each session highlighted how SAP IT is applying these technologies internally, turning strategy into practice and challenges into scalable solutions.

Looking ahead, the second half of the series will shift its focus to AI. Resuming with the series in September, we’ll dive into how SAP is accelerating insights and transforming analytics through AI-powered capabilities. You’ll hear how data and intelligence come together to deliver value across the business, and how we’re transforming user experiences with natural language and automation. The series will then explore further topics such as financial planning, process mining as well as SAP’s own sales transformation, all with the goal to share our insights and lessons learned and to inspire our customers on their journey to bring out their best.

Until then, you can catch up on past sessions and register for the upcoming ones on the event page.

Enjoy the summer and, we look forward to continuing the journey with you soon!

entry.title: How to change posting rules for co-product settlement?
entry.content:
Is there any solution to change the posting rules from production order rather than the material master data in public cloud?

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to change posting rules for co-product settlement?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

In the scenario of Joint Production with Co-Products, settlement rules apply on two levels:

  • On order header: The settlement receivers are order items. The rule determines how the total order costs are distributed over the main product and co-products, that is, over the individual order items.

  • On order items: The settlement receivers are the stocks of each co-product item.

For more information, see Joint Production and Event-Based Cost Distribution (Co- and By-Products).

Event-based posting rules can be displayed and edited in two ways:

  • Use Fiori app Display Posting Rules - Event-Based (F5228): From the order master data screen in the Change Production Order (CO02) or Change Process Order (COR2) app by choosing Header  Settlement Rule, you navigate to the posting rule detail page of the Display Posting Rules - Event-Based app and edit the rule.
     Remember
  • Use RAP business object I_EventBasedOrderPostingRuleTP (Event-Based Manufacturing Order Posting Rule).


For more information, please check Settlement Rules of Manufacturing Orders (Event-Based Posting Rules) and 3042673 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Event-Based Cost Distribution for Co-Products from Order Header to Order Item - SAP for Me 


Best Regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Can ex-post forecast values for each historical period in the Test Phase be in a stored key figure?
entry.content:
I am providing consulting work for a client that uses SAP IBP.

The client wants to know if ex-post forecast values for each historical period in the Test Phase can be in a stored key figure. That way, they can see how each individual period in the error measure calculation horizon was forecasted to compare against actuals, which may help with forecast model selection and/or parameter tuning.

entry.title: Re: SAP MDG: Custom Generic Class for developments
entry.content:
Sorry, I'm having trouble understanding anything from this...

The title says "custom generic class for developments". What "developments"? Why do you need a "generic" class? OK, maybe it's explained in the text.

The text: "several ways to implement it". What is this "it" you speak of? How is "it" related to MDG? 

Next it says "one of the Enhancement UIBB & a Method is GET_DATA" - maybe it makes some sense to the ABAPers who are intimately familiar with MDG but with my general MDG knowledge I struggle to understand what is UIBB and this method. Why did you chose this example and what does it do? 

My professors at the university drilled it into my mind that before any abbreviation is used, it should be explained. I bet many readers are not MDG experts and would appreciate more context.

Then it gets curioser and curioser. "Every time i used to call the below program for different placeholders & for different requirements." OK... Why? What were the requirements? Why did you call this program? I also don't understand what exactly are you referring to as "development placeholder". This isn't official or common ABAP terminology. And why would you need a "placeholder"?

Then "reduce this reusability" - usually we try to improve reusability, not reduce it. But calling the same report(?) is not really a "reusability". 

Consequently, since it's impossible to understand the context and what exactly is the problem, it's also impossible to understand what this code is for. 

Idk, maybe some MDG specialists would be like "right on, I totally get it, super useful", but please be aware that for poor regular ABAP developers like me this post makes no sense. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

entry.title: Re: [S/4HANA Public Cloud] CDS Extraction to SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello @popflorin 

Yes, this is a common setup issue when integrating SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with SAP Datasphere using CDS-based extraction. You’re on the right track, but the issue most likely stems from missing or incorrect Authorization Group ID configuration in the Communication Arrangement.

Follow below steps to fix it

  • Edit the arrangement and set Authorization Group = SAP_DPS_ALL
  • Ensure your CDS Views are released and extraction-enabled (check in View Browser)
  • The communication user needs the right role (e.g. SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR)
  • Even with one CBC, each system (DEV/TEST) needs its own correct communication setup

CDS Views Enabled for Data Extraction-SAP Help

Once these are in place, the CDS views should appear in Datasphere.

Best,

entry.title: Navigating the Final Mile: Best Practices for SAP S/4HANA Cutover Planning and Execution
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA transformation journeys, the cutover phase is often referred to as the “final mile”—and rightly so. It’s the moment where strategy meets reality, and every decision made in prior months is put to the test. A successful cutover isn’t a happy accident—it’s the culmination of precise planning, exhaustive testing, and agile execution.

As someone who has led multiple global SAP S/4HANA migrations across industries and geographies, I’ve seen firsthand the difference between a reactive go-live and a proactive business launch. Below, I share tested best practices for ensuring that your cutover journey ends not in chaos, but in confidence.

1. Cutover Is a Business Event—Not Just a Technical Milestone

A cutover is more than flipping a switch—it’s a coordinated orchestration of business, IT, infrastructure, and partners. Treat it like a product launch. Develop a comprehensive cutover playbook that defines:

  • Task sequences
  • Role responsibilities
  • Timelines and dependencies
  • Communication plans for every stakeholder group

 Pro Tip: Mock cutovers aren’t just practice—they’re strategic simulations. Conduct them with full commitment and seriousness.

2. Cutover Plan: Build. Test. Validate. Refine.

Your cutover plan should go through the same level of rigor as your migration design. It must account for:

  • Data load sequencing
  • Application-specific downtime requirements
  • Backup and recovery checkpoints
  • Contingency and rollback plans
  • Shift-based staffing and escalation models

Create shift-wise execution schedules and real-time tracking dashboards to monitor progress across multiple workstreams.

3. Governance and Communication

Success in cutover lies in the strength of your command structure. Establish a dedicated war room with clear escalation paths, decision-making roles, and aligned communication rhythms.

Build tools such as:

  • Color-coded dashboards (risk/status)
  • Shift handover packs
  • Scheduled broadcast updates to stakeholders 

Pro Tip: Communication should be treated as a formal workstream—complete with check-ins, KPIs, and ownership.

4. Post-Cutover Stabilization

The work doesn’t stop at go-live. Set up structured validation checkpoints immediately after cutover, such as:

  • Reconcile opening balances
  • Validate transactional flows
  • Monitor and resolve migration anomalies

Develop a Hypercare strategy that includes SLA targets, support rotation schedules, and a metrics-driven escalation plan.

5. Institutionalize Lessons Learned

Every cutover reveals insights—capture them. Some recurring pitfalls include:

  • Shrinking validation windows
  • Late-cycle scope creep
  • Overconfidence due to lack of dry runs

Document lessons learned after every cutover and feed them into future readiness planning.

Conclusion

SAP S/4HANA cutovers are high-stakes, high-complexity endeavors. But with a proven framework, stakeholder alignment, and disciplined governance, they can become signature moments of organizational excellence. Cutover doesn’t have to be chaotic. With the right approach, it becomes the launchpad for sustainable transformation.

entry.title: Re: Extending Compensation Planning Publish to Metadata Framework - A step towards Integrated Suite
entry.content:
Hello,

Trying to publish to EC as well as MDF. I am receiving an error when trying to load the modified XML in the instance. The error message is: The content of element type "comp-config" must match "(comp-include?,(comp-number-format|comp-number-format-ext)*,(comp-field-definition|comp-field-group)*,comp-pay-matrix?,comp-currency-conv-table?,comp-stock-value-table?,comp-stock-participation-guideline?,(comp-rule-ref|comp-rule)*,comp-budget-rule*,comp-salary-rule*,comp-force-comment-config*,comp-rating-source*,comp-p4p-common*,comp-rating-input?,comp-display?,comp-instruction*,comp-instruction-tab-name*,comp-calculation?,comp-budget-label*,comp-plan-creation?,comp-manager-hierarchy?,comp-job-selector?,comp-budget-grouping?,comp-budget-override?,(comp-ect-output-component|comp-ect-output-component-group)*,comp-mdf-output-component*,comp-ect-history-config*,comp-group?,comp-variable-pay?,comp-varpay-refs?,comp-custom-action*,executive-review-filters?,ec-publish-filter*,comp-statement-suppression?,profile-access-point?)".

May I suggest that the order in which elements should be placed is important? I followed what you mention: An MDF mapping block using <comp-mdf-output-component> is required to be added to the XML of the plan template and should be positioned after the Budget Override section <comp-budget-override> and then Employee Central publishing  mapping section <comp-ect-output>.

But when I reversed the elements (e.g. comp-ect-output THEN comp-mdf-output-component) I was able to upload without the error.

entry.title: Re: Condition Types in Purchase Orders and Contracts (Hea...
entry.content:
Hello @Shubham120798 

In SAP S/4HANA Public cloud (ULIC 2508), pricing condition types are predefined. Common valuation-relevant ones include PB00 (Price) and FRA1 (Freight) at item level. Header-level types like RA01/RA02 are informational and not valuation-relevant.

You can’t create custom condition types, but you can deactivate or exclude unwanted ones via SSCUIs like 101120 (Define Condition Types) and 101117 (Pricing Procedure).

Only item-level conditions post to accounting. Header-level conditions do not affect inventory valuation

Configuration of Pricing - Purchasing SAP Help

Pricing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Service -SAP Community

With kind regard

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Creation of New Role in Release Strategy in SAP Publi...
entry.content:
Hello @khan_786 

To create a new role for PO release workflow in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  1. Go to Maintain Business Roles app
  2. Create a new role and assign relevant catalogues, example (SAP_MM_BC_PO_WFL_MAINT_PC)
  3. Assign the role to users in Maintain Business Users
  4. In the Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders app, set Assignment By = Role and select your new role

Make sure the role also includes workflow inbox access (SAP_CORE_BC_BAS_WF_INBOX_PC).

Check below SAP Helpful documentations and let me know If it helps

Maintain Business Roles and Business Users

Maintaining Business Roles in SAP S/4HANA, Public Cloud

With regards

Chuma
